statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Appalachian St. 70, Coll. of Charleston 66
article.story: CHARLESTON, S.C. (AP) -- Donte Minter scored 19 points and grabbed 11 rebounds and Jeremi Booth added 10 points off the bench to lead Appalachian State to a 70-66 win over the College of Charleston on Thursday night. The Mountaineers (6-6, 1-2 Southern Conference) traileld 46-39 with 12:22 left and rallied to defeat the Cougars (6-7, 1-2). Minter had four points and Booth a pair of layups in Appalachian State's go-ahead, 10-1 run that put the team ahead 49-47 with 7:36 left. Jeremy Clayton added a pair of free throws with 33 seconds to go that put the Mountaineers ahead 68-63. Donald Sims and Doug McLaughlin-Williams had nine points apiece for Appalachian State. Booth and his fellow reserves were a big reason for the Mountaineers' win. Appalachian State's backups outscored Charleston's 27-21, had 12 steals and got five blocked shots. Charleston was led by Jermaine Johnson's 17 points and 15 rebounds. It was Johnson's sixth double-double in his past eight games. His rebounds matched his previous career high. Tony White Jr. had 13 points and Andrew Goudelock added 12 for the Cougars.
